questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the principle of Prussian blue stain?

A 5-year-old child presents to the clinic with symptoms of irritability, abdominal pain, and vomiting. The physician suspects lead poisoning and orders a complete blood count along with a peripheral blood smear. Which of the following findings would most likely be seen on the peripheral blood smear in lead poisoning?
A peripheral blood smear revealed basophilic granules with Prussian blue stain. Which of the following bone marrow cells are associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Peripheral Smear: Pappenheimer bodies

Bone Marrow: Ringed Sideroblasts
  • Multiple basophilic iron aggregates
  • Stain blue with Perl's/ Prussian blue
  • Seen in sideroblastic anemia, lead poisoning, or hemochromatosis
  • Blue granules form full or partial ring
  • Blasts have a nucleus
  • Iron is present in mitochondria in the perinuclear region.
  • Stain blue on Perl's/Prussian blue.
  • Seen with Sideroblastic anemia and Myelodysplastic syndrome.
  • Associated with SF3B1 mutation


 

Siderocyte (Option B)
  • Red blood cells containing non hemoglobin ferric iron called siderotic granules on peripheral smear Seen in patients with absent spleen, sideroblastic anemia and hemolytic anemia

Reticulocyte (Option C)
  • Immature red blood cells produced in the bone marrow and released into the peripheral blood
  • Brilliant cresyl blue stain
  • Seen in hemolytic anemia, erythroblastosis fetalis and pregnancy.

Bite Cells (Degmacytes) (Option D)


 
  • Bite cells are erythrocytes with irregular membrane due to G6PD deficiency

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, weakness, and pale skin. Her mother mentions that she has developed cravings for ice (pica). Laboratory tests reveal microcytic anaemia, and her serum ferritin levels are significantly low. Which of the following is the most likely infectious cause of her condition?

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a history of treatment for latent tuberculosis presents with fatigue. Physical examination reveals pallor and mild jaundice. Bone marrow smear revealed the following findings.which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Options:
Which of the following new parameters has high specificity for differentiating anemia of chronic disease (ACD) from iron deficiency anemia (IDA)?
questions.correct_answer: B. Serum transferrin receptor (sTfR)/log - ferritin index <1.5
questions.explanation:
Parameter

Finding

Serum transferrin receptor (sTfR)-ferritin index

  • sTfR reflects erythropoiesis, and ferritin describes iron stores.
  • sTfR/log ferritin index > 1.5 in all cases of IDA and ACD with coexisting IDA. (Option A)
  • sTfR/log ferritin index < 1.5 in pure ACD

Reticulocyte index

(Option C)
  • Normal = 0.5-2.5%
  • Reduced in IDA and AOCD
  • Increased in hemolytic anemia.

Blood film morphology

(Option D)
  • Predominantly: normocytic and normochromic anemia.
  • Less commonly: microcytic and hypochromic anemia (also in IDA).

questions.text: A 52-year-old female complains of fatigue, joint pain, and stiffness, especially in the mornings. Physical examination reveals swollen and tender joints in her wrists with ulnar deviation at metacarpophalangeal joints. Which of the following lab findings is not associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Lab Parameters

AOCD

Iron Deficiency Anemia (IDA)

Ferritin

High (Option C)

Low

Transferrin saturation

Low (Option B)

Low

Serum Iron

Low (Option A)

Low

TIBC

Low (characteristic)

High (Option D)

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with a history of breast cancer presents with fatigue and pallor. Laboratory results indicate a hemoglobin level of 9.7 g/dL, low serum iron, elevated ferritin, and low total iron-binding capacity (TIBC). All of the following are true regarding this condition except? Anemia is caused by reduced erythroid progenitor proliferation and iron uptake. Causes include chronic infections, autoimmune disorders and lymphoma. Peripheral smear does not show microcytic hypochromic anemia. All the patients benefit from erythropoietin administration.
Which of the following investigations is the least helpful in determining the underlying cause of anemia?
A 24-year-old female with severe anemia started on parenteral iron. Which of the following would occur first in this patient as a response to therapy?
questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in serum iron level
questions.explanation:
12 to 24 hours

Replenishment of intracellular iron enzymes, decreased irritability; increased appetite, increase in serum iron.

36 to 48 hours

Erythroid hyperplasia in bone marrow

48 to 72 hours

Reticulocytosis, peaking at 5-7 days

4 to 30 days

Increase in hemoglobin level, increase in ferritin, increase in MCV

1 to 3 months

Repletion of stores

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented with easy fatigability and dyspnea on exertion. She was found to have a hemoglobin of 6 g/dL. What will be most likely finding in the peripheral blood smear of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: D. Microcytic and hypochromic red cells

questions.text: A 32-year-old female diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia is prescribed oral iron supplements. Foods containing which of the following can she take to increase iron absorption?

Inhibitors

Ascorbic acid

Tannins

Citric acid

Carbonate

Amino acid

Sugars in the diet

Phosphate

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia, the values of all of the following increase except?
A 10-year-old girl presented with fatigue and weakness. Her laboratory results show reduced hemoglobin, MCV 75 fl, MCH 22 pg and RDW 28. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old male patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia. Which of the following is true about the intracellular regulation of iron in the above condition? IRP- Iron regulatory protein IRE- Iron response elements

options.label: A
options.text: Ferritin translation is increased by binding IRP to IRE.

options.label: B
options.text: Ferritin translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE.

options.label: C
options.text: Transferrin receptor 1 translation is unaffected by binding IRP to IRE.

options.label: D
options.text: Transferrin receptor 1 translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE.

questions.correct_answer: B. Ferritin translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE.

questions.text: Which transport molecule facilitates the absorption of Fe2+ into enterocytes in the small intestine?

A 28-year-old woman presents with fatigue and pallor. Lab tests show hemoglobin of 9 g/dL and MCV of 68 fL. Peripheral smear reveals microcytic and hypochromic red blood cells. Her symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with iron deficiency anemia. Which of the following statements regarding iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is correct?

options.label: B
options.text: Serum ferritin is the gold standard investigation

options.label: D
options.text: Serum ferritin levels are not affected.

questions.explanation:
Iron Study

Interpretation in Iron Deficiency Anemia

Serum Ferritin

Low (< 30 ng/mL) indicates depleted iron stores.

Serum Iron (Fe)

Low levels are seen in iron deficiency anemia.

Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)

Increased TIBC reflects the increased capacity of transferrin to bind iron in response to low iron stores.

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW)

Increased RDW is often seen in iron deficiency anemia

Bone Marrow Aspiration and Iron Staining

Confirmatory test

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman has been experiencing fatigue, pallor, and shortness of breath for the past six months. Laboratory tests reveal a Hb of 6 gm/dl. Red cell distribution width is increased. Peripheral smear is shown below. Where is the likely site of absorption of the micronutrient deficient in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Duodenum

Jejunum

Ileum

Colon

Iron

Folic acid, amino acids, glucose, fatty acids

Vitamin B12, bile salts

Water, electrolytes like sodium and chloride, vitamins

questions.text: All of the following are causes of microcytic hypochromic anemia except?
questions.explanation:
Microcytic Anaemia

Normocytic Anaemia

Macrocytic Anaemia
  • Sideroblastic anemia.
  • Iron deficiency anemia.
  • Thalassemia.
  • Anemia of chronic disease.
  • Lead poisoning.
 

(Mnemonic- SITAL)
  • Acute Blood Loss
  • Hemolytic Anaemia (hereditary spherocytosis)
  • Anemia of Chronic Disease
  • Bone Marrow Disorders (e.g., Aplastic Anaemia)
  • Renal Disease
  • Endocrine Disorders (e.g., Hypothyroidism)
  • Early stages of Iron Deficiency Anemia
  • Vitamin B12 Deficiency
  • Folate Deficiency
  • Alcohol Abuse
  • Liver Disease
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Myelodysplastic Syndrome
